lines.text: You know about Satan and idle hands, don't you?
Oh yes! I've heard about them. Both!
After all, time does heal all wounds.
Does it?
No arguing about it. There's no arguing with any of the old sayings because that's why they are old 'cause they tell the truth, and the truth lasts.
I've had a poem running through my mind for a long time now. It's one that Christopher Marlowe wrote. It's... uh... well, listen.
[begins]

Come live with me and be my love, and we will all the pleasures prove that hills and valleys, dales and fields, woods or craggy mountains yeild. And I will make ye beds of roses and a thousand fragrant posies...
[pauses]
and... and... something, something, something, something...
[remembering]
And if these pleasures do ye move, come live with me and be my love.
You see, I have to have a husband, and you said you weren't married. So...?
Well, Miss Jones, a wife is just what I don't need.
But you do need money. I thought we could trade. I'll have a husband, and you'll have money.
Well what are we going to do?
We are going to take what's left to us. Why we haven't even a minute to waste on being sad. Come on. Let's hurry.
Well where should we go?
Oh I don't care. Just so there are people and music and we can be gay.
Grandma always puts me in my place.
Sit down, Miss Jones. There where I can see you.
Thank you.
Pretty, aren't you?

[embarrassed]
oh!
Never mind me. When you get old, time is too precious to waste. If people are pretty, you tell them so. And you're pretty.
Part of living is meeting tragedy and rising above it. A woman doesn't amount to anything unless she can do it. It takes a long while to learn that that's true.
Thank you for telling me.

[about her blackberry brandy]
Blackberries will do a lot for you, if you just squeeze them and then leave them alone.
Works the same way with the women folks.
